node.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Forced Cinderella to Scrub the Stage Floor’
node.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
node.content: ["On a brisk November morning, I found myself climbing a fruit tree in my mother\u2019s backyard in suburban Virginia. My 3-year-old insisted that I pick the last persimmon at 6:30 a.m. My father planted that tree two decades ago because the persimmons reminded him of the home he left behind in Korea. Now each year, come Thanksgiving, the tree bears vibrant orange fruit on the grayest of almost-winter mornings, and I am reminded of him. I think of how he would have held his granddaughter\u2019s hands, had they been given the chance to meet. \u2014 Heidi Shin", "In second grade, I was cast as Cinderella\u2019s wicked stepmother in my school\u2019s medley of fairy-tale skits. Tall, with dark hair pulled back, I forced Cinderella to scrub the stage floor. With a body I thought was too big for fairy wings, I ached to be fragile. Backstage, I playfully shoved my crush Vito (dressed as one of the three little bears). He fell back, squashing Tinkerbell\u2019s wings. Everyone hurriedly helped her. I felt shame. Had Sister Rosemary sensed my inner wickedness and cast me accordingly? She found me hiding and whispered in my ear, \u201cYou were magic out there.\u201d \u2014 Lisa Fogarty", "Three weeks after my 89-year-old mother broke her pelvis, she steered her walker to the bathroom sink. Her dementia led her to believe that I was her friend Shirley. Muscle memory took hold when she opened the medicine cabinet. She removed a cracked tube of Cherry Frost lipstick and painted her mouth in bold strokes. Laughing, she said, \u201cThis is funny: Two old girls putting on lipstick.\u201d Her blue eyes sparkled. \u201cI wish someone would sneak up and take a picture of us.\u201d I pulled my smartphone from my bathrobe pocket. We grinned. One with lipstick. One without. \u2014 Karen Buley", "Lou and I fit together like interlocking fingers, but I didn\u2019t know how much I loved him until the day a speeding taxi missed him by the width of a fingernail. For whatever reason in that moment, I thought of his side of the room we call our office, a jumble of precarious stacks of stuff that no effort at feng shui could fix. After the cab whizzed by, we hugged and shivered. Through my tears, I smiled up at him and said, \u201cSomething good has come of this. From now on, you can be as messy as you like.\u201d \u2014 Leida Snow"]
